He is applying for his first loan of KES 40,000 from KADET LTD., with which he plans to purchase more stock of items like sugar, flour, breads and many others.

He will use the anticipated profit to expand his business and educate his children. He hopes to expand his business to be a wholesale instead of a retail shop. He is very hardworking.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of items like sugar, flour, bread and many others.

loans.name: Lucia

texts.en: Lucia has five children. All of the children are in school. She is a widow. She has been in this business for two years. She took a loan from BRAC South Sudan to expand her business. The profit that she will earn from the business, she will use to pay school fees.

loans.use: to purchase more cold water and soda to sell

loans.name: Abdalla

texts.en:
Abdalla is a married man with four children, all of whom attend school. He owns a house that has electricity and piped water. His greatest monthly expenses are food and rent bills. 

For the past 20 years, he has operated a charcoal selling business, selling from home to his neighbors and passersby. He also sells firewood, which contributes to his other source of income. He faces a major challenge of seasonality in his business. Abdalla dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier of firewood in the future. 

With the 15,000 Kenyan shillings, he wants to purchase bundles of firewood and 10 sacks of charcoal for his business. He decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost his business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of firewood and 10 sacks of charcoal for his business.

loans.name: Fatuma

texts.en:
Fatuma is a married woman with three children; two attend school while one is still too young for school. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a street-food selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a restaurant in the future.

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to establish a food stall business and purchase sacks of cereals, wheat flour and maize flour. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To establish a food stall business and purchase sacks of cereals, wheat flour and maize flour.

loans.name: Gladys

texts.en:
Gladys is a married woman with three children, all of whom attend school. She lives at a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are rent bills, school fees and food for the family.

For the past five years, she has operated a second-hand clothes selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Her challenge in the business is seasonality. During the rainy season, the demand for heavy clothing increases while the demand for light clothing decreases. She dreams of becoming the leading supplier of second-hand clothes in the future.

With the 40,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.en:
Nancy is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling retail at the market to her neighbors and passersby. The major challenge in her business is seasonality, especially the changes in climate that affect the type of clothing and demand in the market. She dreams of expanding her business in the future.

With the 25,000 Kenyan shillings, she wants to purchase bales of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Floice

texts.en:
Floice is a married woman with one child who attends school. She lives at a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

With the 20,000 Kenyan shillings she is requesting, she wants to start a boutique business and purchase bales of clothes to sell on a retail basis to her neighbors and passersby. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale shop in the future. Floice decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bales of clothes.

loans.name: Estrella

texts.en: Estrella is 52 years old and lives in Dipolog City. She is married with three children. To earn a living, Estrella has a business selling fruit. She earns about PHP 1,000 each month doing this type of work. Estrella has requested a loan of PHP 3,000 to purchase fresh fruits to sell. Estrella has been a member of PMPC just this year.

loans.use: to purchase fresh fruits to sell

loans.name: Alma

texts.en:
Alma is 43 years of age and married. She has been engaged in the rice farming business for almost 11 years. She is thankful because she has been blessed with three school-aged children. 

Alma is able to earn PHP 24,000 per cropping during the April and September seasons. She aims to give her children a good education through the rice farm she manages. In this regard, she would like to ask for a loan of PHP 18,000 to buy fertilizer and insecticides and pay for the labor cost of transplanting and sowing of crops in her rice farming business. She hopes that she can maintain her business to be able to send her children to a higher level of education.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer and insecticides and to pay for the labor cost of transplanting and sowing the crops

loans.name: Olimjon

texts.ru:
Олимчон добрый и целеустремленный отец.   Он женат и любящий отец 6 детей. Олимчон преподает в среднем школе № 5 в местном городе. Олимчон старается зарабатывать много  денег, потому что у него очень большая семья и ему не хватает зарплата, которую он получает в школе.  И так он решил заниматься выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур с целью получение прибыли. Он выращивает фрукты, и овощи затем продает их в своем магазине. Кроме этого он имеет еще один доход.  Он занимается скотоводством. Олимчон хотел бы получит кредит в размере 1000$ США для покупки горюче смазочные материалы и крупного рогатого скота.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en:
Olimjon is a good and dedicated father. He is married and the loving father of six children. Olimjon teaches at middle school number 5 in his town. Olimjon is trying to make a lot of money because he has a very big family, and does not make enough money teaching at school.  So he decided to start farming to make a profit. He grows fruit and vegetables and then sells them in his shop. He also has another source of income. He breeds cattle. Olimjon would like to receive a loan of $1000 to buy fuel, lubricants, and cattle.

loans.use: to buy fuel, lubricants, and cattle.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To purchase chicks and sacks of charcoal for resale and to pay for rural electrification in her home.

loans.name: Mwanasiti

texts.en:
Mwanasiti is a married woman who lives in a rental house that has electricity but not piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past three years, she has operated a clothes-selling business, selling at retail to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. Her major dream is to expand her existing business in the future.

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase bundles of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Jemma

texts.en:
Jemma is married with two children. Jemma is 30 years old and lives in Tangub City.

Jemma sells bananas to earn a living and has had this business for five years. Each month, she earns PHP 5,000 doing this type of work. She has requested a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase more bananas for her retail business.

Jemma has been a member of PMPC for two years.

loans.use: to purchase more bananas to sell

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
This is Anita, 40, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Her husband is Frederick, a warehouse man. She is a mother to her four children. Her eldest child is in college and the youngest is in elementary school.  She, together with her husband and children, manages their household while operating the business.

Anita operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Anita earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of PHP 300 in sales every day.

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a PHP 21,000 loan. She will use the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Anita hopes to be able to expand soon and dreams of being able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work in her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to sell

loans.name: Janet

texts.en:
Janet is a married woman with two children, both of whom attend school. She lives in a rental house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is house rent.

For the past five years, she has operated a vegetable stall business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her major dream is to expand her business in the future.

With the KSHS 30,000, she wants to purchase sacks of potatoes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of potatoes for resale.

loans.name: Lory

texts.en:
Lory is 32 years old and lives in Helen Village, Larena, Siquijor Province.  She is single mother of two children.

To earn a living, Lory has a business selling snacks. She earns about PHP 4,000 each month doing this type of work.  Lory has requested a loan for 7,000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

Lory has been a member of Paglaum Multi Purpose Cooperative for eight months.  In the future, Lory would like to support the basic needs of her two children.
.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business

loans.name: Lucy

texts.en: Lucy is 41 years old and married to Nicholas. They have two children. She has been running her transportation business for the past five years with a monthly profit of KES 8,000. She has been loaned KES 30,000, which she plans to use to service the car and buy spare parts. With the anticipated profit, she plans to build her family a home. In the future, she hopes to buy another car.

loans.use: to service the car and buy spare parts

loans.name: Bintihamisi

texts.en:
Bintihamisi is a single woman with four children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a food stall business, selling from home to her neighbors and passersby. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. She dreams of establishing a beauty salon business in the future.

With the KSHS 40,000, she wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour and cooking fat oil. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase bundles of wheat flour and cooking fat oil.

loans.name: Suzi

texts.en: Suzi has two children. Both of the children are in school. She is a married woman. She took a loan from BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business. She said that the extra income from this loan will help her to build a small shop.

loans.use: to purchase more sugar to brew waragi to sell

loans.name: James

texts.en: James is 23 years old. He is a hardworking and born-again Christian who aspires to have a good life. For the last three years, he has been making a living by operating a motorcycle business. He makes an extra shilling from the salary he gets from his employment. He wants in the next five years to have ventured into other businesses so he becomes financially stable. He is requesting a loan of 30,000 Kenya shillings to buy a motorcycle. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for empowering him financially and training him on business management skills.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle

loans.name: Cecilia

texts.en: Cecilia is 37 years old and married with two children aged 10 and 17 years old.  For nine years, she has been operating a green grocery.  She also sells cereals.  She owns rental houses, which earn her extra income.  Previously, she was selling clothes to earn a living.  Through Faulu Kenya, she has been able to boost her business. Cecilia hopes to own more rental houses for more income generation in the future.  She has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy cereals.

loans.use: To buy cereals

loans.name: Gundsamba

texts.en: Gundsamba is 24 years old and lives in a rented ger, a Mongolia yurt, with his brother and mother, in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. His youngest brother graduated from college this year but is still unemployed. He and his older brother started a grocery business five years ago. He is planning to own the food court land in the future. Gundsamba graduated from the University of Agriculture in 2011.  He is a polite and kind man. He is requesting 600,000 MNT to purchase more inventories for his food sales during the Naadam festival and increase the sales turnover.

loans.use: To purchase more inventory for his grocery store

loans.name: Florence

texts.en: Florence is 39 years old, married and blessed with two children. For eight years, she has been operating a retail shop.  She also does farming to earn extra income for her family.  In addition, she owns rental houses. Being a member of Faulu Kenya, she has benefited because she has boosted her business with her previous loans. Florence hopes that one day; she will open a wholesale business.  She has requested 40,000 Kenya shillings to buy sugar, maize flour and detergents.

loans.use: To buy sugar, maize flour and detergents

loans.name: James

texts.en: For the last 15 years, James, 42, has been operating a general store to make ends meet. He makes an extra shilling by engaging in farming. He wants in the next five years to have a better business premises and a high turnover.  He is married and blessed with three school-going children. He is requesting a loan of 45,000 Kenyan shillings to buy wheat flour, rice, biscuits and sanitary pads. He is grateful to Faulu Kenya for reducing his stress levels and advancing him finances to use in his business.

loans.use: to buy wheat flour, rice, biscuits and sanitary pads

loans.name: Mwanajuma

texts.en:
Mwanajuma is a married woman with five children, all of whom graduated from school. She owns a house that has electricity and piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, she has operated a clothes selling business, selling at the market to her neighbors and passersby. Her major challenge is theft because of insecurity in her area of operation. She dreams of establishing a boutique to sell clothes in the future.

With the 100,000 KES, she wants to purchase bundles of lesos (rectangular-shaped patterned cloths) for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of lesos for resale.

loans.name: Vincent

texts.en:
Vincent is thirty years old and single. He has been running his business for the last two years making a monthly profit of 6,000 KES. He has been loaned 30,000 KES and he plans to use the whole amount to purchase waste paper for sale and use.

With the anticipated profit made, he plans to advance his education. In the near future he hopes to start a paper industry.

loans.use: to purchase waste paper for sale and use

loans.name: Rose

texts.en: Rose is 30 years old. She has two children. Both of her children are in school. She is a married woman. She has been in this business for two years. Rose requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase more soft drinks.

loans.use: To purchase more cold water, soda and mango juice to sell

loans.name: Isabella

texts.en:
Isabella was born in 1989 and is the single mother of two.  To earn a living, she sells vegetables.  Her business is three years old and she has employed one person.  Her business is located in the slum area so most of her customers are low income earners, but she is able to make enough income for her family.

Isabella  was previously selling cereals.  She is very grateful to Faulu Kenya because she was able to buy rental houses which generate more income for her family.  She has requested 40,000 Kenyan shillings to buy a weighing machine and vegetables.

loans.use: to buy a weighing machine and vegetables

loans.name: Clive Road Women's Group A

texts.en:
Most budding and fledgling entrepreneurs in Uganda have gone through the mill and did get apprentice business training. That statement should be taken with a grain of salt. It may be a little farfetched, but one can’t rule out the fact that indeed some entrepreneurs did get some business training.

A study carried out recently showed how some business people are nodding acquaintances when it comes to efficiently operating businesses. That proficiency is lacking, but still most businesses, however petty they are, are making headway. This has puzzled most business experts, but it is the status quo that we are all bearing witness to.

If the above, particularly the part that talks about the fact that most people lack business training, is referenced to 42-year-old Kate, an assiduous clothes sales business entrepreneur plying her trade in Jinja, it could hold water. It’s now 15 grueling and chequered years in this business for Kate, who at her age has no kids yet.

She says being devoid of business skills has not played havoc with any of her operations, though she says if she had got the training, she probably would be operating her business in a more worthwhile and proficient way.

Her maiden business was a retail shop and Kate says she utilized her savings to set forth in her cloth sales trade. However, she has not dispensed with her retail shop. She still operates it, though she has delegated the responsibilities of running it to her sister.

She says this business's monthly sales income totals up to 150,000 Ugandan shillings. This is the fourth time Kate's group is taking a loan from Pearl microfinance and their track record in repayments has been good.

Kate says she reckons that with this Kiva loan she will purchase more clothes, principally men's clothes, to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes, principally men's clothes, to resell

loans.name: Anorboi

texts.ru:
Анорбой добрый и ответственный муж.   Он женат и любящий отец 3 детей.  Когда он был маленьким, его отец занимался  выращиванием сельскохозяйственный культур и скотоводством и он помогал отцу.  Таким образом, он изучал все слабые стороны данного бизнеса и в настоящее время, он продолжает данный бизнес с легкостью. С прибылью, который он получает от данного бизнеса, он тратят для нужды семьи и расширение бизнеса. Анорбой хотел бы получит кредит в размере 2200$ США для покупки скота и минеральных удобрений.  Прибыл, который он планирует, он хочет отремонтировать своего дома.

texts.en:
Anorboi is a good and responsible husband. He is married and the loving father of three children. When he was young, his father was a farmer, and he helped his father. Thus, he learned all about the business and now he continues to do this work with ease. With the profits he receives from his business, he supports his family and expands the business. Anorboi would like to receive a loan of $2,200 to buy livestock and fertilizers. When his investment pays off, he wants to renovate his home

loans.name: Meali

texts.en:
Meali is a single woman with two children, all of whom attend school. She owns a house that has piped water but no electricity. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees.

For the past two years, she has operated a grocery selling business, selling from home to her neighbours and passersby. Her major challenge is the high costs of transportation in her business. She dreams of expanding her business and establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the 80,000 KES, she wants to purchase bundles of bananas, oranges, tomatoes, vegetables and potatoes. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of bananas, oranges, tomatoes, vegetables and potatoes

loans.name: Mary

texts.en: Mary is 39 years old. She has three children. All of the children are in school. Mary is a widow. She sells charcoal and cooking oil in Kator market.  She took a loan from BRAC South Sudan with the hope of expanding her business.

loans.use: To purchase or order more charcoal to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase 30 pieces of khangas to offer for resale

loans.name: Bibi

texts.en:
Bib is a single woman who lives at a family house with electricity but no piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her young siblings.

With the Kshs 20,000 loan she wants to start a clothes-selling business by purchasing bundles of clothes for resale. She dreams of expanding the business and incorporating cloth materials in the future. Bib decided to work with Yehu to access loans to boost her business and improve her livelihood.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Mishi

texts.en:
Mishi, a married woman with two children, both of whom graduated from school, owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family.

For the past four years, Mishi has operated a business selling cashew nuts at the market to her neighbours and passersby. She faces the major challenge of seasonality due to change in the climate. Mishi dreams of becoming a wholesale supplier of cashew nuts in the future.

With a loan of Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase two sacks of cashew nuts for resale. Mishi decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: to purchase two sacks of cashew nuts for resale.

loans.name: Perizat's Group

texts.en:
Perizat leads this loan group. She is 25, married to a builder and earns 5,000 soms a month by working as a waitress. She and her husband have a five-year-old daughter. Perizat has applied for this loan because she plans to start her own business. She will use the money to buy stationery, which she will sell on the open market. Her goal is to buy enough money to buy a house and a vehicle. 

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy stationery to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Vivian

texts.en:
This is Vivian, 47, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. Her husband is Edwin, a businessman, and a father to her three children. Her eldest child is in college and the youngest is in elementary school. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating a business. 

Vivian operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five peso's-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Vivian earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 600 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 22,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory and for the maintenance of her sewing machine. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Vivian hopes her business grows into a mini-grocery and dreams to be able to give her children a good and high quality education through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business

loans.name: Mahmadrajab

texts.ru:
Махмадрачаб женат и отец 3 детей.  Он очень трудолюбивый и добрый человек.  Его ценят все его соседи и друзья. Он всегда помогает другим и сделает добро. Более 14 лет он занимается выращиванием сельскохозяйственных культур. За многие эти годы он изучал все слабые стороны данного бизнеса и набрал достаточное знание, чтобы продолжат и развивать данный бизнес в дальнейшем.  Махмадрачаб хотел бы получит кредит в размере 1000$ США для покупки скота, горюче смазочные материалы, минеральных удобрений и семена с целью расширения бизнеса и получение прибыли. Заранее хочет поблагодарит вас за вашу поддержку.

loans.name: Babacar

texts.fr: Monsieur Babacar est un jeune homme de 38 ans . Il est marié et père de 2 enfants qui ont entre 1 et 3ans. Depuis 1989 il exerce la couture comme  activité principale. Il dispose d’un atelier qui lui est propre depuis 2000. Il a choisi cette activité par amour du métier. En plus il est issu d’une famille de tailleur car son père et sont frère ont la même vocation. Ses périodes favorables sont la Tabaski, la korité et le gamou  qui sont des fêtes nationales  pendant lesquels la  majeure partie de la population  fait appel aux services des tailleurs  au Sénégal. Parallèlement  avec son activité de tailleur Babacar  s’adonne souvent au commerce de tissus. Il est sociétaire de UIMCEC depuis février 2010. Il sollicite un crédit de 200 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de thioups  destinés a la vente en vue des préparatifs des fêtes de korité .Babacar est un chef de famille qui souhaite accroitre ses revenus pour mieux prendre en charge la dépense quotidienne de sa famille. Il ambitionne aussi d’accroitre son épargne afin de pouvoir réaliser quelques projets
texts.en:
Mr. Babacar is a young man of 38.  He is married and the father of two children between one and three years old.  Since 1989 his primary occupation has been tailoring, and he has owned his own workshop since 2000.  He chose this business out of love for the trade, and he also comes from a family of tailors since his father and brother share the occupation.  His busiest periods are the Tabaski, Korité, and Gamou, which are national holidays during which most of the population of Senegal uses the service of a tailor.  

In addition to his tailoring business, Babacar sells fabric.  He has been an account holder at Baye Iaye since February 2010.  He is requesting a loan of 200,000 frs to purchase indigo-dyed fabric to resell in preparation for the Korité festivities.  Babacar is a head of family who wants to increase his income to better meet his family’s daily expenses.  He also hopes to increase his savings in order to carry out several projects.

loans.use: to buy fabric for resale.

loans.name: Elvira

texts.en:
This is Elvira, 56, a resident of Pasay City, in the Philippines. She is married to Juanito, a tricycle driver, and a mother of two children who already have their own families. She, together with her husband, manages their own household while operating the business. 

Elvira operates a food stall. In the Philippines, the whole working community and most of the families only eat home-cooked meals during evenings where all of the family members are at home to take part in the meal. 

This is not only a typical family tradition but also a matter of convenience and frugal living. It is considered a waste of money and time to use cooking gas and food for one to two persons when buying cooked rice and viands costs less than raw food. 

Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 750 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more  products like meats, rice, vegetables, condiments and seasonings. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Elvira dreams to make this store a mini-grocery. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where he can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God he studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for raw ingredients needed in her business

loans.name: Bosco

texts.en:
Bosco is a thirty-eight-year-old married man with five children who owns a house in Kasese, Uganda. 

He has been operating a retail shop for five years which he started with 500,000 shillings. He now has 3,000,000 shillings as his working capital. His hardship is the lack of enough capital to purchase the desired goods; his vision is opening another shop plus educating his children. 

Bosco intends to use the loan to buy sugar and rice for reselling.

loans.use: To buy sugar and rice for reselling.

loans.name: Toktokan's Group

texts.en:
Toktokan is a member of this group. She is 47 and unfortunately she is a widow. She has raised three daughters; the older daughter is married and lives separately with her family and the other two daughters are employed. 

In order to earn money to meet the family's daily needs Toktokan cultivates agricultural products. Selling some part of the harvest she earns 1000 soms per month. She applied for a loan because she needs money to purchase fertilizer. In the future Toktokan wants to see her daughters get married. 

---Where Did This Loan Come From?---

This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused microfinance institution in Kyrgyzstan. 

MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only microfinance institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a Video presentation about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 

If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our lending team Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers

loans.name: Topista

texts.en:
Topista is a forty-seven-year-old widow with twelve children who rents a house in Kasese, Uganda. Ever since her husband died she has been solely taking care of the children amidst a number of challenges, and her dream is to educate them up to the university level. 

She has had a bar for fifteen years, and it is profitable. Her hardship is the lack of enough capital to supply her increasing customer base, and her vision is having a lodge and modernizing the bar, plus educating children. 

Topista needs the loan to buy beer for her bar.

loans.use: To buy beer for her bar

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase more potatoes for use

loans.name: Lourdes

texts.en:
This is Lourdes, 63, a resident of Pasay City, Philippines. She is a widow with 2 children, both are already working. Together with her children, she manages their household while operating the business.

Lourdes operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, 5 PHP-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. Lourdes earns her income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 550 PHP in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a 9,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Lourdes hopes her business will grow into a mini-grocery and dreams of being able to give her children a good future through all her hard work on her business. Every week, she faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and other products needed in her business

loans.name: Aberi

texts.en: Aberi is a 40-year-old, married man with 5 children living in his own house in Fort Portal, Uganda. The responsibility to look after the family solely rests on him and his dream is to set up a sustainable income-generating activity. Aberi has been a fish vendor for 10 years. His hardship is limited funds to purchase enough fish to meet the high demand of customers. Aberi needs the loan to buy fish for resale.

loans.use: to buy fish for resale

loans.name: Moussa

texts.fr:
Monsieur  moussa est un jeune commerçant  marié  de 38 ans qui habite  au Senegal. Il évolue dans la vente de tissus depuis plus de 5ans. Il place sa marchandise et fait une collecte journalière pour entrer dans ses fonds.  C’est une activité qu’il a choisi par amour. Ses meilleurs moments pour son activité correspond aux veilles de fêtes comme la tabaski et la korité. 
Moussa est sociétaire au guichet de Baye Laye depuis Juin 2001. Il sollicite un crédit de 150 000 frs  prévu pour l’achat de tissus  destinés a la vente. Son objectif est de faire face a l’accroissement de la demande avec le démarrage du ramadan au Sénégal. L’amélioration de ses gain lui permet de mieux prendre en charge les dépenses liées au quotidien et d’assumer ses responsabilités de chef de famille.
texts.en:
Monsieur  Moussa is a young small-scale retailer, married, 38 years old, who lives in Senegal. He has been developing his cloth sales business for more than five years. He places his merchandise and then collects on a daily basis to get his funds back. He chose this business because he likes it. The best times for his sales are the period just before the holidays such as "Tabaski" and "Korité" (Muslim feast days).

Moussa has been a member of the Baye Laye branch since June 2001. He is requesting a loan of 150,000 francs to buy cloth for resale. His objective is to keep up with the growing demand at the beginning of Ramadan in Senegal. The increase in his income will permit him to do better at covering his day-to-day expenditures and to fulfill his responsibilities as the head of his household.

loans.use: to buy lengths of cloth for resale.

loans.name: Kymbatbu's Group

texts.en:
Kymbatbu is 40 years old and leads this loan group. She lives in the coal-mining town of Tashkomur with three children. Her husband makes a living as a welder, while she earns an income as a seamstress and clothing designer. Doing this type of work has been her passion since childhood and she was able to turn it into a profession in 1995. Over time, she has built up a relationship with textile suppliers and people who buy her products, which are unique in their quality and beauty. Most of her clients are women, so Kymbatbu recently added household items to the list of products she sells. She earns about 9,000 soms a month, and is applying for this loan to buy more fabric and materials to use in making new masterpieces.  

--- Where Did This Loan Come From? ---
This loan is brought to you by Mol Bulak Finance (MBF), a young, ambitious and socially-focused Microfinance Institution in Kyrgyzstan. 
MBF is strongly committed to the principles of sustainable development and upholds the triple bottom line – People (building human capital and taking care of its customers as well as society), Planet (keeping environmentally friendly) and Profit (earning revenue to expand autonomously). MBF is the only Microfinance Institute in Kyrgyzstan that delivers its services to customers 365 days a year. To learn more about MBF and view a video about the organization, please visit: http://www.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=135 
								
If you would like to support and learn more about Kyrgyzstan and microfinance in Central Asia, please join our Lending Team - Supporters of Kyrgyzstan – Mol Bulak Finance at http://kiva.org/team/kyrgyzstan. Members will get special updates and news from Kiva Fellows in Kyrgyzstan and from the MBF staff.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and materials.

loans.name: Lilan

texts.en: Lilian is 43 years old, married and the mother of four children. She earns about KES 7,200 a month selling garments, such as lesos and vitenge, which are popular among local women.  She is applying for a loan for KES.15,000 to buy more of these items to sell to her customers. Her goal is to expand her business and open a store where she can sell her products.

loans.use: to buy women's garments to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Clive Road Women's Group B

texts.en: Harriet is 32 years old and runs a fast-growing business selling food in the town of Jinja, which is located in Central Uganda. She is the mother of two children and known for her diligence, grit, steadfastness, perseverance and determination. Harriet wants to continue expanding her business, and is applying for this loan to buy more of the supplies she uses to make the food items she sells, including sugar, salt, cooking oil, maize flour and rice.

loans.use: to buy supplies for a food-vending business.

loans.name: Gulgumcha

texts.ru:
Гулгумча замужем и любящая мать 3 детей. Она активная и целеустремленная женщина. Она занимается продажей парфюмерий и косметики в центральном местном рынке. Более 5 лет она занимается в этом бизнесе, и она имеет много постоянных клиентов. Она обслуживает все свои клиенты с улыбкою и с радостью. Гулгумча хочет, расширит свой бизнес и пополнит свой оборотный капитал.  С этой целью она просила кредит в размере 3000$ США. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

IMON's History

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en:
Gulgumcha is married and the loving mother of three children. She is an active and purposeful woman. She sells perfumes and cosmetics in the local market. For more than five years, she has worked in the business, and she has many loyal customers. She caters to all of her customers with a smile and with joy. Gulgumcha wants to expand her business and add to her working capital. To this end, she has requested a loan of $3000.

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

Since December 2007, IMON International has worked closely with Kiva and Kiva lenders to ensure that poor and low income clients represent a viable business proposition. Funds raised through Kiva have already been distributed to thousands of IMON International's clients and will continue to provide thousands more with permanent access to the varied financial services they need. To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj

loans.use: to buy perfumes and cosmetics.

loans.name: Mame  Cheikh

texts.fr: Mame Cheikh est un tailleur qui exerce cette activité depuis 2002. C’est depuis 1999 après qu’il ait interrompu ses études  qu’il a commencé à être  initié dans ce métier.  Il vit au Sénégal depuis sa naissance . Il est membre d'un des guichets de l'U-IMCEC  depuis janvier 2010. Il sollicite un crédit de 250 000 frs prévu pour l’achat de tissus qui seront utilisés pour la confection d’habits destinés a la vente. Son ambition est de mieux rentabiliser son activité en cette   période  de début de ramadan pour ainsi augmenter ses bénéfices en faisant face a la forte demande de service de veille de fête.Son ambition est d' acquérir une autonomie financière pour mieux assister sa famille.
texts.en:
Mame Cheikh is a tailor who has been in this business since 2002. It is since 1999, after he interrupted his studies, that he began learning this trade. He has been a member of the Baye Laye branch since January 2010. He is requesting a loan of 250,000 francs to use for buying cloth that he will sew into clothing which he plans to sell. His ambition is to make his business more profitable during this period where Ramadan is beginning so that he can earn more, become financially independent, and better help his family. 

Note: Mame Cheikh employs apprentices in his sewing workshop and it is one of the apprentices who is photographed here. Mame Cheikh was absent when the photo was taken.

loans.use: to buy cloth to sew for resale.

loans.name: Birajab

texts.ru:
Бирачаб честная и целеустремленная женщина.  Она замужем и  мать 4 детей. Более 12 лет она занимается куплей продажей женских тканей.    Она имеет арендованную торговую точку, где она может торговать. Она занимается одна в этом бизнесе. Она приобретает товар с рынка  города Душанбе, Истаравшан а также с города Дубай.   Бирачаб брала кредит уже 3 раза и погасила успешно. Среди клиентов она имеет хорошую репутацию и кредитную историю. Бирачаб хотела бы получит еще кредит в размере 1600$ США для покупки материалов с целью расширение бизнеса. 

More about Tajikistan and IMON International

Tajikistan is known for its rich history, which includes a key post along the Silk Road and the end of Alexander the Great's rule. It has also produced great thinkers, philosophers, scientists and poets, including Rudaki, Avicenna, Ferdowsi, Omar Khayyam, Jomi, and Rumi. The country is home to communities that still speak the ancient Sogdian language, epic mountain passes, and a civilization that dates back to the 4th millennium BC. And, even today, it is a complex mixture of the Islamic faith, Soviet culture, New West culture and Central Asian traditions.

But Tajikistan is also the poorest of the former Soviet republics. The civil war, which ignited soon after its independence from the U.S.S.R., further damaged the already weak economy. In addition, 93% of the country is mountainous and only 7% of the land is arable. These conditions have resulted in high levels of unemployment and have forced hundreds of thousands to seek work in other countries, mainly Russia. While the people of Tajikistan are working to improve its agricultural production and manufacturing sector, nearly two-thirds of the population still live in abject poverty.

To learn more about IMON International's work, please visit: www.imon.tj
texts.en:
Birajab is an honest and dedicated woman. She is married and the mother of four children. For more than twelve years, she has worked buying and selling women's fabrics. She rents a shop. She works alone in her business. She buys the goods from the market in Dushanbe, as well as from Istaravshan and the city of Dubai. Birajab has taken out three loans and paid them off successfully. As a borrower, she has a good reputation and credit history. Birajab  would like to receive another loan of U.S. $1,600 to purchase materials to expand her business.
